comments.commentBody:
Ted @64: Well said.

Carlie @69: Righteous.
Ricky is never boring. Bring him back anytime.....
Shame about Jesse Eisenberg.  Looks like the Foreign Press Corps, mainly British, stayed with their roots on this one.  I thought they were cooler than that.

Some commenters in this forum have blamed the Obama administration for TARP, the protection of too-big-to-fail (TBTF) financial institutions, and the near-elimination of dividends; and some have observed, perhaps more correctly, that the Bush administration (especially Goldman Sachs fraternity member Henry Merritt "Hank" Paulson, Jr) is to blame. It should be noted that both JPM's Jamie Dimon and his favorite federal regulatory playmate, the FDIC's Sheila Bair, have been united in their ideological certainty that shareholders must take the hit for the failures of corporate management. (Neither has advanced an opinion on the failures of federal regulatory agencies; Mr Dimon hires from agencies such as the SEC.) Since it is the Obama administration that is currently in a position to attempt to reform our toxic financial system, it would be prudent to examine how those in power might influence the future flow of dividends.

James Lieber, writing in the Village Voice, advised, in October, 2009:

"People who expect President Obama's Department of Justice to take the lead will be severely disappointed — not necessarily because the task is difficult, but because the Obama administration is showing that it lacks the will.

Instead, the new administration is putting its energy into creating what it believes will be a meltdown-proof new system of elite 'too-big-to-fail' banks, regulated by a beefed-up Federal Reserve."

Further,

"...the nation's new top prosecutor, Attorney General Eric Holder, has a history of preferring that deviant corporations be held to no more than a 'voluntary cooperation' system in which they investigate themselves privately.

Under the 'Holder Memo,' which he wrote in 1999 as deputy AG in the Clinton administration, bad-boy executives and their corporations who turn over evidence to the government qualify for lenient sentences and fines and, sometimes, for settlements without even indictments. The consequences of their crimes often amount to only the cost of doing business.

After leaving government, Holder followed the mandates of his own memo and made a lucrative living by conducting internal probes for companies and negotiating outstanding results for white-collar clients. He was public about it: Holder's 2002 op-ed 'Don't Indict WorldCom' in The Wall Street Journal argued on behalf of the corporate perpetrator of one of the sleaziest frauds of the past decade."
http://www.villagevoice.com...

Louise Story, writing in this newspaper last month about "the secretive banking elite [that] rules trading in derivatives," quoted an anonymous DOJ spokeswoman in saying that "[t]he department’s antitrust unit is actively investigating 'the possibility of anticompetitive practices in the credit derivatives clearing, trading and information services industries.'"
http://www.nytimes.com...

Investors, it would seem, would be wise to take a circumspect position regarding the dividends distributed by the TBTF institutions that circumscribe virtually every interpretation of "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness."

Citibank is instituting a $100 or $200 annual fee on their investment accounts in 2011. When I called and told them I considered this an huge annoyance considering they are giving me .002 interest rate on my small balance of cash and that the 4 mutual funds I have will never regain the value they had, the rep said he understood and that he heard the same from every caller since the notice went out

So in essence, fees on loyal sucker customers if now funding these dividends and microscopic interst paid to customers if funding these dividends.

When I move my funds and balance out Citibank will nail me for a $95 closing fee also

Is it possible, do you suppose, that since the big banks have revised their rules for checking accounts that that is where a good part of their fat purses is coming from?  How much "float" do you calculate each has (nationally) to play with now that we have to maintain an average balance as high as $1,000 (that I know of) in order to avoid a monthly charge plus fees?  In one sense we, the depositors, can consider that interest earned on our $500 or $1,000, which will sit unavailable to us, but I consider it highway robbery.  They already have the float on our transactions, some states allowing banks to hold deposits from out-of-state for three business days before making the funds available to the depositor.

another way they are making money... firing human cashiers and replacing them with self checkout. I'm appalled to see my east hampton CVS chasiers who i have known for years - disappear only to be replaced by machines. I think cvs will be the last place I will be shopping!

This probably means people will eat even more packaged and processed food. While my gourmet market has plenty of fresh produce, they also have a lot of packaged produce, including supposedly organic apples that have been sliced, put in single serve plastic bags, and several bags inside a plastic tub. Dreadful.

Most Walgreens I've been to don't have the parking to handle greater customer loads.  Food products seem to languish on the shelves longer making me question their freshness. Sushi and lettuce aren't band-ades and cosmetics.

When drug stores start carrying fresh groceries, because of reduced sale volume the grocery stores will start losing money, and their profits will decline. In that case they will close their stores or raise their prices. The prices of fresh grocery at drug stores are already high as they are not that efficient in handling that business. The result will be consumer will lose.  My suggestion to the drug stores is: leave the fresh grocery business to the grocers.

Sure, it's great that more urban areas may gain a neighborhood location for fresh fruits and vegetables, but are the people who need that the most going to pay that much for them? Once again, a good idea that only caters to the people who aren't going to care.
This must indicate that there is profit in selling groceries!
Super Target already have grocery for a long time now. Also, the size of stores like CVS and Walgreens are getting bigger and bigger.

This is interesting. I'm surprised chains like 7-11 aren't jumping into this gap. Having seen a 7-11 in a Tokyo residential neighborhood, which despite its small footprint seemed to fulfill the role of a Walgreens, Target and Safeway in one, it's interesting to see the company's US stores remaining mostly empty space, punctured by big gulps.

but "seasonal" stuff is carried for very short periods, in very small amounts - this allows stores like CVS to make customers pay for stuff.
Lets say CVS stocks summer basics, like flip flops, for only a momth in may; you have to go in, get your flipflops and pay up front; cvs gets the money and no inventory or holding cost
the other thing I have noticed, at least in my town, walgreens is much better then cvs; W usually has a wider range of items at lower cost
was this article written 10 years ago or something?  BC I've seen groceries in my CVS for about that long now.

Every linear foot of shelf space has to generate a profit. A lot of firms overstuff the stores, the result is a lot of stale dated goods on the shelf, with a loss of confidence in the stores. Tracking the expiry dates of identical items in various stores will often reveal the relative health of the stores.

Funny...the Kroger near me has as much space dedicated to cosmetics and OTC drugs as the average drug store has.  How long will it be that every big box sells the same stuff..you then just shop for convenience

I drive out from Manhattan the Target in Queens.   Always stocked up on boxed food there.  It is much cheaper than in "the city".  But thats where the deals end.  They put in a new fresh produce section and the bannanas are all rotten, selection awful, and OJ more than some places here in the city.  Like most NY'ers, we will but the deals/quality and leave the "rotten bannanas" for the rest.

The main reason these drugstores are selling groceries is that there are, sadly, nearly 45 million Americans on foodstamps and they are just trying to tap into those sales.  If all the Americans on foodstamps were standing out on breadlines like during the depression, people would be horrified to realize - against the corporate media and Obama administrations fake recovering economy hyperbole - that we are doing much, much worse than many have been told.

This is good though as the article points out, it can be a bit more expensive. My local CVS/pharmacy seems to charge a premium on snacks and groceries while some of those same items (pasta, milk, etc.) cost a little less at Walgreens. I have to actually like grocery shopping at Targét as prices are more on par with the Raleys and Safeways here in NorCal. I really like the Market Pantry brand of sliced turkey breast.:)

The whole re-orientation of both CVS and Target is very disconcerting, especially when it results in the elimination or sizing down of the reasons I go to them. Target, for instance, totally eliminated not only its garden department, but all of the everyday shelf items that relate to gardening.

The food choices at CVS are very narrow and pedestrian. And most of these stores are near enough to full service and cheaper grocery stores that this change will not bring me in any more often than before. In fact, so far I have been going in less.
This a sure way to get government money through the Food Stamps program.
I love buying groceries at the drugstore.  Grocery stores are thieves selling identical products for 75% more money.

I found it diplomatic to disable the car by disconnecting the ignition wire. We avoided searches for the keys that way and could offer to check into repairing her car tomorrow and offer to take her where she wanted to go. She usually wanted to go "home," although she was already there and would recognize that we were now home after driving around for a while.
